meanings.def: the mixture of gases that surrounds the earth and that we breathe
examples: Let's go out for some fresh air.
a blast of hot air
currents of warm air
He stood outside, breathing the cold night air.
She was gasping for air as she ran out of the burning house.
whales coming up for air (= in order to breathe)
I need to put some air in my tyres.
The agreement requires reductions in air pollution.
The Act lays down a minimum standard for air quality.
I kicked the ball high into the air.
I opened the window to air the room.
He left most of his property to his eldest son and heir.
He drew in another breath of air.
I sat for a moment, inhaling the fresh forest air.
It's difficult carrying such heavy loads in the thin air of the mountains.
Land crabs breathe air and cannot swim.
The cool night air wafted in the open windows.
There are regulatory requirements for clean air and water.
They have developed an engine powered by compressed air.
We felt a blast of cold air as she opened the door.
the musty smell of stale air
the polluted air of our cities
warm currents of air
Nothing moved in the still air.

meanings.def: the space above the ground or that is around things
examples: Music filled the night air.
in/into the air Wave your hands in the air!
I kicked the ball high into the air.
through the air Spicy smells wafted through the air.
He punched the air in triumph.
The air was thick with cigarette smoke.
The tang of some wild herb hung in the air.
Suddenly a scream pierced the air.
The air was sweet with incense.
The dog stretched and sniffed the air.

meanings.def: the space above the earth where planes fly
examples: The temple was clearly visible from the air.
We watched as the helicopter took to the air.
by air It only takes three hours by air (= in a plane).
air travel/traffic
air defence systems (= weapons that defend against attacks from the air)
A surprise air attack (= from aircraft) was launched at night.

meanings.def: the particular feeling or impression that is given by somebody/something; the way somebody does something
examples: She looked at him with a defiant air.
air of something The room had an air of luxury.
There was an air of complete confidence about her.
He had an air of mystery about him.
He leaned over to Melissa with an air of confidentiality.
You have an air of authority.

meanings.def: a tune
examples: Bach’s Air on a G string

meanings.def: a way of behaving that shows that somebody thinks that they are more important, etc. than they really are
examples: I hate the way she puts on airs.

meanings.def: a way of behaving that shows that somebody thinks that they are more important, etc. than they really are
examples: Even when he became a star he didn’t have any airs and graces.

meanings.def: clean air breathed in after being indoors or in a dirty atmosphere
examples: We'll get a breath of fresh air at lunchtime.
I'm going outside for a breath of fresh air.

meanings.def: (to have) plans or dreams that are not likely to happen or come true
examples: As a child he would wander round the boatyards, building castles in the air about owning a boat one day.

meanings.def: to improve a difficult or tense situation by talking about worries, doubts, etc.
examples: This meeting will be an opportunity to clear the air and start the healing process.

meanings.def: to make the air less dirty or less humid (= warm and wet)
examples: Storms were supposed to clear the air.

meanings.def: to disappear suddenly in a mysterious way
examples: She can’t just have vanished into thin air.
At a stroke she could make things vanish into thin air.

meanings.def: used to refer to an estimate or method of doing something that is not very accurate or scientific and partly based on guessing
examples: It isn’t an exact science—it’s a kind of finger in the air thing.
‘It’s all a bit finger in the air,’ admitted a spokesman.

meanings.def: to feel very happy
examples: Most couples feel they are walking on air on their wedding day.

meanings.def: felt by a number of people to exist or to be happening
examples: There's romance in the air.

meanings.def: broadcasting or not broadcasting on television or radio
examples: We will be back on air tomorrow morning at 7.
The programme was taken off the air over the summer.

meanings.def: from nowhere or nothing, as if by magic
examples: Unfortunately, I can’t just conjure up the money out of thin air!

meanings.def: to say a name, number, etc. without thinking about it, especially in answer to a question
examples: I just plucked a figure out of the air and said : ‘Would £1 000 seem reasonable to you?’

meanings.def: not yet decided
examples: Our travel plans are still up in the air.

meanings.def: in a way that is not friendly and suggests that you think that you are better than other people
examples: She walked in with her nose in the air, ignoring everyone.

examples: Even when he became a star he didn’t have any airs and graces.

meanings.def: to put clothing, etc. in a place that is warm or has plenty of air so that it dries completely and smells fresh; to be left to dry somewhere
examples: Air the sheets well.
Leave the towels out to air.
I kicked the ball high into the air.
I opened the window to air the room.
He left most of his property to his eldest son and heir.

meanings.def: to allow fresh air into a room or a building; to be filled with fresh air
examples: The rooms had all been cleaned and aired.
Leave the window open to air the room.

meanings.def: to express your opinions publicly
examples: The weekly meeting enables employees to air their grievances.
The issues were openly aired and discussed by the group.

meanings.def: to broadcast a programme on the radio or on television; to be broadcast
examples: The show will be aired next Tuesday night.
The program aired last week.

meanings.def: to discuss your personal affairs in public, especially something embarrassing

idioms.idiom: air/wash your dirty laundry/linen in public
idioms.def: to discuss your personal affairs in public, especially something embarrassing
